thread.title: Best cash Isa 'Nisa' rates

author: Sophie Christie
title: Best cash Isa 'Nisa' rates
text: Savers can now put up to £15,240 in a cash Isa for the 2015-16 tax year. Here, we name the top fixed-rate cash Isas (where your money is locked into a specified rate for the whole term) and the top easy-access Isas (where the rate is variable, but you can access your money as many times as you want). Bookmark this page – updated on a regular basis – for the latest Isa deals or opt for our weekly money round-up . Don't forget that there are alternative accounts that could pay more on your savings pot, such as high-paying current accounts. See our favourites here . BEST FIXED-RATE DEALS ONE YEAR: Nationwide is offering a rate of 1.65pc on balances above £1. Transfers in are allowed, and the account can be opened online or in branch. Interest paid annually or monthly. TWO YEARS: Kent Reliance pays 1.85pc on balances above £1,000, with old Isa money accepted and interest paid annually or monthly. THREE YEARS: State Bank of India pays 2.1pc on deposits of £15,000 or more. Old Isa money can be transferred, but customers must hold or open a State Bank of India online instant-access savings account (paying 1.25pc on minimum deposits of £500) in order to open the Isa. For smaller deposits, Nationwide pays 2pc on balances above £1, with transfers-in allowed. FOUR YEARS: The best four-year account on the market is offered by Coventry Building Society , paying 2.1pc . The account can be opened online, by post or in branch, but does not accept old Isa money. A minimum deposit of £1 is required. FIVE YEARS: State Bank of India pays 2.5pc on balances above £15,000. Same conditions as above apply. For smaller deposits Coventry Building Society offers a rate of 2.4pc on £1 or more. Transfers-in not allowed. BEST EASY-ACCESS DEALS Nationwide's "Flexclusive Isa" (issue 9) pays 1.6pc on balances above £1. Savers must also hold a "Flex" current account. Transfers in allowed, and the account is available online or in branch. [NOTICE ACCOUNT] Hinckley and Rugby Building Society pay 1.6pc on deposits above £500. Withdrawals are subject to 120 days notice or loss of interest. It does accept transfers, but from Hinckley and Rugby Isas only. National Savings & Investments (NS&I) is paying 1.5pc with no withdrawal restrictions. The "Direct Isa" needs an opening deposit of £1, but does not accept transfers in from other providers. [NOTICE ACCOUNT] Clydesdale and Yorkshire banks also pays 1.5pc , but withdrawals are subject to 40 days notice or loss of interest. Transfers in are not allowed. Interest is paid annually. The interest rate depends on the balance in the account; 1pc is paid on balances between £1 and £8,999, 1.5pc is paid on balances between £9,000 and £23,999, and 2pc is paid on balances over £24,000.
